articles.headline: Justices Tell Judges Not to Rule on Major Backers
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court ruled that the Constitution can require elected judges to step aside from cases involving people who spent exceptionally large sums to put them on the bench.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court ruled that the Constitution can require elected judges to step aside from cases involving people who spent exceptionally large sums to put them on the bench.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Elected judges must disqualify themselves from cases involving people who spent exceptionally large sums to put them on the bench, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday in a 5-to-4 decision.

articles.headline: Questions About a Desert Village
articles.snippet: Investors in an “eco-village” of lakes, pools and 2,500 villas in Abu Dhabi have started a campaign to force the developer to push ahead with the project.
articles.abstract: Investors in an “eco-village” of lakes, pools and 2,500 villas in Abu Dhabi have started a campaign to force the developer to push ahead with the project.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI  The Middle East property boom has produced more than its share of dream-spinners and deal makers, whose brash attitudes eventually dwarfed the villas and towers they promised to build.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Delays Sale of Chrysler to Fiat
articles.snippet: If the U.S. Supreme Court decides to hear an appeal that lasts weeks or months, it could put Chrysler at risk of going out of business.
articles.abstract: If the U.S. Supreme Court decides to hear an appeal that lasts weeks or months, it could put Chrysler at risk of going out of business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s effort to hurry Chrysler through bankruptcy court ran into an unexpected last-minute delay on Monday, when the Supreme Court said it could consider whether to hear the objections of three Indiana state funds and consumer groups.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Economy Shows Cracks in European Union
articles.snippet: European leaders, preoccupied with domestic politics, are fighting over how to combat the economic slump, protecting jobs at home at the expense of fellow members.
articles.abstract: European leaders, preoccupied with domestic politics, are fighting over how to combat the economic slump, protecting jobs at home at the expense of fellow members.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN  The European Union is an extraordinary experiment in shared sovereignty, creating a zone of peace that now stretches from Britain to the Balkans. The union of 27 countries is the world’s most formidable economic bloc, incorporating 491 million people in an integrated market that produces nearly a third more than the United States.

articles.headline: Shell to Pay $15.5 Million to Settle Nigerian Case
articles.snippet: The European oil giant Shell had been accused of being complicit in the executions of the activist Ken Saro-Wiwa and other critics of Nigeria’s former government.
articles.abstract: The European oil giant Shell had been accused of being complicit in the executions of the activist Ken Saro-Wiwa and other critics of Nigeria’s former government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Royal Dutch Shell, the big oil company, agreed to pay $15.5 million to settle a case accusing it of taking part in human rights abuses in the Niger Delta in the early 1990s, a striking sum given that the company has denied any wrongdoing.

articles.headline: High Gas Prices Could Slow Recovery
articles.snippet: The national jump in prices is far larger than the normal seasonal increase and threatens to curtail a modest recovery in consumer spending on items like apparel and electronics.
articles.abstract: The national jump in prices is far larger than the normal seasonal increase and threatens to curtail a modest recovery in consumer spending on items like apparel and electronics.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  After just a few months of relief at the pump, cheap gasoline is disappearing.

articles.headline: Boston Globe Union Rejects Deal on Pay Cuts
articles.snippet: The union at The Boston Globe narrowly rejected cuts despite threats of deeper reductions in pay from The New York Times Company, which owns the paper.
articles.abstract: The union at The Boston Globe narrowly rejected cuts despite threats of deeper reductions in pay from The New York Times Company, which owns the paper.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  After weeks of labor tension and 12 hours of suspenseful voting, members of the Newspaper Guild at The Boston Globe narrowly rejected a proposed package of wage and compensation cuts. As a result, the newspaper’s owner, The New York Times Company, said it would proceed with its threat to unilaterally impose a 23 percent salary cut.

articles.headline: In Ads, Banks Try the Warm, Cozy Approach
articles.snippet: Financial institutions are burnishing their images for public opinion and to try to influence lawmakers.
articles.abstract: Financial institutions are burnishing their images for public opinion and to try to influence lawmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is Ally Bank: “A better kind of bank.” And A.I.U.: “A unique franchise.” And  really  Redneck Bank: “Where bankin’s funner!”

articles.headline: 10 Large Banks Allowed to Exit U.S. Aid Program
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and eight other large banks were deemed strong enough by federal regulators to return more than $68 billion in taxpayer aid.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and eight other large banks were deemed strong enough by federal regulators to return more than $68 billion in taxpayer aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration marked with little fanfare a major milestone in its bank rescue effort  its decision on Tuesday to let 10 big banks repay federal aid that had sustained them through the worst of the crisis  as policy makers and industry executives focused on the challenges still before them.

articles.headline: 7 Indicted on Charges of Selling Tax Shelters
articles.snippet: Questionable tax shelters earned their promoters hundreds of millions of dollars in fees and continue to plague the tax advisory industry.
articles.abstract: Questionable tax shelters earned their promoters hundreds of millions of dollars in fees and continue to plague the tax advisory industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities on Tuesday obtained an indictment against a former chief executive of the accounting firm BDO Seidman on charges of conspiracy, fraud and lying to the Internal Revenue Service in connection with his work on questionable tax shelters sold to wealthy investors.
